issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
(Not sure which Components to fill in)

Repro'd twice in a row since yesterday:
http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4154/
http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4166/

Did a Quick Launch Master, changing the topology to be a one-host cloud (to save EQS machines usage), which I do regularly when I don't need multi-host:

{noformat}
machine-topology:
  - cloud-components:
    - clc
    - walrus
    - cc
    - sc
    - ufs
    - nc
    - console
    cluster-name: one
{noformat}

...running no tests, CentOS 7, no selinux, Edge mode, master from packages. No errors from Calyptos, and no errors in the VLM or euca logs.

Upon logging in, {{euserv-describe-services}} says:

{noformat}
euserv-describe-services: error: connection error (('Connection aborted.', error(111, 'Connection refused')))
{noformat}

Specifying the region doesn't help, same error:

{noformat}
euserv-describe-services --region admin@a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
{noformat}

If I assume system credentials, it works. But then I can't do any other commands like euca-describe-volumes. Same error as above.

Something has changed ( ? ) since the last time I launched a 1-node cluster without this error on 2-Jun-2016. Haven't gotten a 1-node cloud to deploy without this problem since, only did the 2 launches above.

The .euca/euca-admin.ini looks fine:

{noformat}
[region a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com]
user = 000675016782:admin
autoscaling-url = http://autoscaling.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
bootstrap-url = http://bootstrap.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
cloudformation-url = http://cloudformation.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
ec2-url = http://ec2.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
elasticloadbalancing-url = http://elasticloadbalancing.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
iam-url = http://iam.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
monitoring-url = http://monitoring.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
properties-url = http://properties.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
reporting-url = http://reporting.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
s3-url = http://s3.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
sts-url = http://sts.a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/

[user 000675016782:admin]
key-id = AKIAABDZ3IYJJ7TCKOZS
secret-key = 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
account-id = 000675016782

[global]
default-region = a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
{noformat}

Nothing useful in VLM or the Euca logs.

I tried these commands to set it up again, to no avail, same resulting .ini file (except new keys) and same error from cmds:

{noformat}
   35  euare-userdelkey AKIAA3GCBSW2C7Z7O6U5
   36  export DOMAIN=`euctl system.dns.dnsdomain | sed "s/.* //g"`
   37  echo $DOMAIN
   38  export PREFIX=`echo $DOMAIN | sed "s/\..*$//g"`
   39  echo $PREFIX
   40  euare-useraddkey -w -l -d $DOMAIN admin > ~/.euca/$PREFIX.ini
   41  cat ~/.euca/a-38.ini
   42  echo "" >> ~/.euca/$PREFIX.ini
   43  echo "[global]" >> ~/.euca/$PREFIX.ini
   44  echo "default-region = $DOMAIN" >> ~/.euca/$PREFIX.ini
{noformat}
fields.summary: Creating 1-node Quick Launch cloud, if console is included, leaves admin user unable to run commands

comments.body: [~lincoln.thomas]: let's try again today (lots of instability yesterday) and, if still problematic, reach out to [~mbacchi].

I created two one-node clouds today, with and without eucaconsole included in the topology:

With console: http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4197/

{noformat}
machine-topology:
  - cloud-components:
    - clc
    - walrus
    - cc
    - sc
    - ufs
    - nc
    - console
    cluster-name: one
{noformat}

This cloud has the reported problem, commands are refused:

{noformat}
[root@d-14 ~]#  euserv-describe-services
euserv-describe-services: error: connection error (('Connection aborted.', error(111, 'Connection refused')))
[root@d-14 ~]# euca-describe-volumes verbose
euca-describe-volumes: error: connection error (('Connection aborted.', error(111, 'Connection refused')))
[root@d-14 ~]#
{noformat}
But the console itself works fine, from my Firefox.

Without console: http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4198/

{noformat}
machine-topology:
  - cloud-components:
    - clc
    - walrus
    - cc
    - sc
    - ufs
    - nc
    cluster-name: one
{noformat}

This cloud works fine!

Am I defining the topology wrong?

Hmm, the problem doesn't seem to depend on the presence of eucaconsole. Reviewing the deployments in the original description, this one has the console, and commands don't run (same as console cloud above):
http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4154/
However, this one does NOT have the console, and commands still don't run:
http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Master/4166/

So, I don't know what causes it or not.
Assigning back to the EQS team.

[~lincoln.thomas] we will look into it. Something is not right with DNS lookups or something in this topology. As a workaround you can specify the region as localhost.

not specifying a region (which looks to the config file in which uses endpoint DNS names)
{code}
[root@g-08-10 ~]# euca-describe-images
euca-describe-images: error: connection error (('Connection aborted.', error(111, 'Connection refused')))
{code}

using region localhost
{code}
[root@g-08-10 ~]# euca-describe-images --region admin@localhost
IMAGE	emi-83e8630b	eucalyptus-service-image-v2.40/eucalyptus-service-image.raw.manifest.xml	000733573297	available	private	x86_64	machine				instance-store	hvm
TAG	image	emi-83e8630b	provides	imaging,loadbalancing
TAG	image	emi-83e8630b	type	eucalyptus-service-image
TAG	image	emi-83e8630b	version	2.40
{code}
unassigning this to hit bug scrub again. I think there is a euca bug here and nothing to do with EQS.

Thanks Tony for the workaround, that does work for me.

Earlier, I had tried:

{noformat}
euserv-describe-services --region admin@a-38.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
{noformat}
...which also failed. But using {{@localhost}} instead of the domain name just now worked.

If this is an intermittent issue, it may explain cases I've seen (non-reproducible) over the past few months where the DNS names for buckets I use in S3/OSG work seem to vanish after restarting eucalyptus-cloud, and I have to revert to IP numbers, running e.g. s3curl commands from a client machine. Once they vanish, they never come back even after subsequent eucalyptus-cloud restarts and system reboots. Those were always on 1-node clouds.

This may be related to networking configuration, specifically br0:

{code}
# ip addr show
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN 
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
    inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
    inet6 ::1/128 scope host 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
2: em1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq master br0 state UP qlen 1000
    link/ether d0:67:e5:ea:67:4a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet6 fe80::d267:e5ff:feea:674a/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
3: em2: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST> mtu 1500 qdisc noop state DOWN qlen 1000
    link/ether d0:67:e5:ea:67:4b brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
11: br0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP 
    link/ether d0:67:e5:ea:67:4a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet 10.111.5.138/16 brd 10.111.255.255 scope global dynamic br0
       valid_lft 20468sec preferred_lft 20468sec
    inet 10.111.31.160/32 scope global br0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
    inet6 fe80::d267:e5ff:feea:674a/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
12: em1.107@em1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP 
    link/ether d0:67:e5:ea:67:4a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet 10.107.105.138/16 brd 10.107.255.255 scope global em1.107
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
    inet6 fe80::d267:e5ff:feea:674a/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
13: em1.116@em1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP 
    link/ether d0:67:e5:ea:67:4a brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet6 fe80::d267:e5ff:feea:674a/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
14: vn_i-ec811561: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc pfifo_fast master br0 state UNKNOWN qlen 500
    link/ether fe:0d:ec:81:15:61 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet6 fe80::fc0d:ecff:fe81:1561/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
{code}

which has the ip we should return 10.111.5.138 and the one we actually return 10.111.31.160:

{code}
# dig ec2.d-14.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.111.5.138

; <<>> DiG 9.9.4-RedHat-9.9.4-29.el7_2.3 <<>> ec2.d-14.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com @10.111.5.138
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 25507
;; flags: qr aa rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 1

;; OPT PSEUDOSECTION:
; EDNS: version: 0, flags:; udp: 4096
;; QUESTION SECTION:
;ec2.d-14.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
ec2.d-14.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. 60 IN A 10.111.31.160

;; Query time: 15 msec
;; SERVER: 10.111.5.138#53(10.111.5.138)
;; WHEN: Wed Jun 08 16:18:56 PDT 2016
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 87
{code}

I think you should be able to work around by binding specific addresses for DNS:

{code}
# euctl --region admin@localhost dns.dns_listener_address_match=10.111.5.138
{code}

but this does not appear to be working (still binds all addresses)

This may be due to host mapping behaviour in TopologyDnsResolver as the listener cidr 10.111.5.138/16 also matches the 10.111.31.160 host address. If this is the issue then a simple solution is to check if the host is localhost and use the listener address in that case.
DNS host mapping now prefers the listener address when mapping for local services.
[~sjones], thanks! I deployed a 1-host cloud and it passed the EQS concise2 regression tests, and seems to be working fine!

Fix Verified.

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.3.0
Release     : 0.24985.321.20160614git42985d3.el7

1 node cloud deployments are again feasible.
Successful deployment via EQS: http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Calyptos/6021/
